Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Oxygen, Ecology and the Cambrian radiation of Animals
Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaborative Research: Oxygen, Ecology and the Cambrian radiation of Animals

David Johnston, Harvard University
Lisa Levin, Scripps Institute of Oceanography

The Cambrian radiation, during which essentially all major animal body plans appeared in the fossil record ~540 million years ago, is one of the most important evolutionary events in Earth history. In recent years, hypothesized triggers for this event have focused on a rise in predation and increased levels of oxygen in the world's oceans. We propose to test the linkage between these hypotheses. We postulate that the high oxygen demand of carnivory (animals feeding on animals) is the key linkage. The hypothesis outlines that carnivory (animals eating other animals) was limited by low levels of atmospheric oxygen. As the late Precambrian Earth transitioned to a more oxygenated state, this lifestyle (carnivory) and ultimately the Cambrian explosion ensued. Here, we will test both the biological and geological predictions of this hypothesis. The biological prediction, that oxygen limits carnivory in animals, will be tested by constructing and analyzing a database of published marine bottom dwelling animal surveys, coding how each animal feeds, and examining how oxygen levels and other environmental parameters affect feeding behavior. The geological prediction, that oxygen increased near the Precambrian-Cambrian boundary, will primarily be tested by generating sedimentary geochemical data (focusing on iron, carbon and sulfur) from the spectacular Neoproterozoic stratigraphic record of northwestern Canada in the Ogilvie, Wernecke and Mackenzie Mountains. Together, these two tests of this integrative causal hypothesis for the Cambrian radiation will provide new insight into this important geobiological event.
This grant provides funding to train two levels of researchers. First, the grant provides funding for a post-doctoral scholar who will work between the Principal Investigators at Scripps and Harvard to accomplish the goals of the proposal. The post-doctoral scholar will also will work with the Center for Ocean Sciences Education Excellence to deliver a filmed public lecture in the Perspectives on Ocean Sciences series at the Birch Aquarium. These are widely distributed talks (broadcast to 15 million homes; ~200,000 web views per year) and will be instrumental in disseminating the results of the modern global ocean compilation to the public and demonstrating how ancient oceans can inform responses to modern oceanographic change. Second, two undergraduate students, one from Harvard and one from an undergraduate-oriented institution, will gain both field experience in northwest Canada and lab experience in sedimentary geochemistry through this grant.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In sedimentary rocks older than 540 million years there are very few fossils that likely represent the remains of animal life (and even these are very contentious). Yet just after 540 million years ago, essentially every major animal body plan known from the modern ocean can be found in the fossil record. The sudden appearance of all these animal groups is known as the Cambrian radiation, and it represents one of the most intriguing evolutionary events in Earth history.  Hypotheses to explain this event have included increasing oxygen levels in the ocean at this time, and the origin of the first predators, which drove body plan innovation through predator-prey ‘arms races.’ Recently, it has been hypothesized that these two triggers for the event may be linked, as carnivorous feeding strategies have high oxygen demand.

            This grant tested both the ecological and geochemical aspects of this prediction. The biological prediction that low oxygen limits carnivory in animals, was tested by constructing and analyzing a database of modern marine bottom-dwelling animals from published ecological surveys, coding how each animal feeds, and examining how oxygen levels and other environmental factors affect feeding behavior. These analyses demonstrated that oxygen levels are the strongest control on animal diversity and feeding strategies, but that the response is strongest at low oxygen levels—above a certain level, other environmental factors such as temperature and food supply are more important. The geological prediction was tested by collecting sedimentary rock samples from multiple regions (including northwest Canada, western United States, and Namibia), and conducting iron geochemical analyses that reveal the oxygen levels of the ocean water column above the accumulating sediment. These analyses were combined with all previously published results, and analyzed collectively and statistically for the first time. These analyses did not find evidence for an oxygenation event around 540 million years ago, suggesting that if there was an oxygenation event at this time, it was lower in magnitude than the sensitivity of this aggregated data. This suggests that, contrary to most current hypotheses, the oceans and atmosphere did not become oxygenated to modern levels at this time period. Interestingly, the demonstration that the strongest effects of increasing oxygen on animal ecology occurs at the lowest O2 levels leaves open the possibility that smaller magnitude oxygenation could still have played a critical role in triggering the Cambrian radiation. More precise data on the magnitude of oxygenation in the Cambrian and the response of animals to increasing oxygen levels will be required to fully address this new scenario.

Broader Impacts: This grant supported the post-doctoral research and professional development of Dr. Sperling, including mentoring and training. As part of this grant, Dr. Sperling gained experience supervising three undergraduate senior honor theses in sedimentary geochemistry in the lab of Dr. Johnston. Two students conducted international fieldwork with Dr. Sperling, and all three students generated quality iron, carbon, and sulfur geochemical data from over 70 samples/student. One student earned co-authorship on two manuscripts and the other two students are expected to earn authorship on future manuscripts. Thus, this grant provided valuable mentoring experience for Dr. Sperling and well-structured field and laboratory research experiences for the undergraduate students.
